conversation.content: Is this the ferry to the island?
Indeed it is—we depart in precisely seventeen minutes. The crossing takes forty-two minutes in calm seas; today's running about forty-six with the eastern swell.
You seem very exact about that.
Twenty-three years piloting this route, you learn the rhythms. Every wave pattern, every wind shift... they all speak their own language if you listen close enough.
That's a long time doing the same route.
Same route, different ocean every single day. Yesterday we had dolphins racing the bow for seven minutes; Tuesday, a fog so thick you couldn't see your own hand.
Do you ever get bored?
Bored? Never—the water's always teaching you something new. Last week I discovered a two-degree course adjustment saves three gallons of fuel per crossing.
Three gallons doesn't sound like much.
[yawn] Four crossings daily, six days a week... that's 3,744 gallons annually. Small adjustments compound into massive changes over time—that's the secret of navigation.
You calculated that in your head?
Numbers are just patterns; once you see them clearly, they practically solve themselves. Like how this ferry weighs 847 tons but displaces exactly the right amount of water to float.
How do you know all this stuff?
You spend enough time with something, it becomes part of you. I can feel when we're two pounds over optimal trim just by how she responds to the wheel.
Two pounds? That's impossible.
The ferry speaks through vibrations—frequency changes at different loads. Most people can't hear it, but after two decades, your body becomes a tuning fork for the ship.
You're not really human, are you?
Human as they come, just... attentive. The ocean demands complete presence; half-attention gets people killed out here, so you learn to notice everything.
Everything?
[very meekly] Well, almost everything. Still can't figure out why the vending machine on deck two only takes quarters on Thursdays.
